There’s an also an app you can download on your phone (at least if you’re in the U.K.) called “Dream Lab”.  The idea is that you put your phone on charge at night, open the app and it does Science from your phone while you’re not using it.  They recently added a COVID-19 section specifically to help tackle it, but usually the app is for fighting cancer, so even when this pandemic is done, you can still be a sleep hero!
There  is  a  very  good  Wikipedia  page  on  Folding@home .

Similar to Folding@Home, you can also do World Community Grid, which currently has a COVID project! It also has other projects related to TB, childhood cancer, AIDS, Ebola, and so on. You can opt-in to as many projects as you're interested in (but your computer will only run a few at a time so as not to overload your system).

In addition to Folding at Home you also have BOINC/Rosetta at Home for pc, and the Dreamlab app for smart phones. The last one haven't received enough credit yet, and is very easy to use for everyone with a smart phone.

0:55 - "[...] why Covid-19 looks so different from person to person."

There are two obvious reasons:
1) False positive tests using the PCR tests have already been shown to be common and might make up more than half of the official "infected".

2) Patients that tested positively where often treated with remdesivir or chloroquin (Resochin), which where hastily approved in march.
Both have shown in trials to cause side effects that would fit the more severe cases of Covid-19, especially in NYC.

You might want to make a SciShow Episode: "How do we treat Covid patients right now"

EDIT: They already had an episode about Hydroxychloroquine, briefly stating the risks (G-6-PD deficiency).
But they completely ignored the fact, that it gets used ANYWAY.
Up to 20% of male african-americans have the deficiency that causes HCQ therapy to destroy their red blood cells.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=va6j4JITJoE

EDIT2: They also included Remdisivir in an episode on April 19th, again completely ignoring how widespread the use already was at that time.

Vitamin D3 fights covid19. D3 levels are related to the seriousness of the CCP19 virus symptoms.

And some doctors are reporting that when people catch the virus, HCQ + zinc is about 90% effective when given by doctors in the early stages. (President Trump was right).

One recent study showed that people with low levels of vitamin D3 in their blood were much more likely to have severe symptoms of covid19 infection.

Another recent study showed 10 times more deaths in covid19 patients with low levels of vitamin D3 in their blood.

Other nutrients are also very important. Sufficient vitamin C is needed to get zinc into our cells where zinc can block virus replication.

Blood clots are a serious problem with bad covid19 infections. L-arginine is known to reduce unwanted blood clots.

Should doctors test everyone's nutrient levels or at least provide or recommend nutritional supplements?

Is it possible to reduce the percentage of covid19 patients that have severe symptoms by taking quality nutritional supplements?

Keeping our nutrient levels optimized for optimum health is possible but easier said than done. I know that I don't eat a perfectly balanced diet and I don't spend time in the sun every day, especially during lockdown. How many frontline health care workers are getting the sun and the nutrients they need for optimal health?

Most people are showing no to mild symptoms from covid19, without treatment.

If we keep our nutrient levels optimized, our bodies have a better chance of overcoming covid19 infection.

There's another distributed computing project for folding simulation called Rosetta@home. Rosetta has a different aim than Folding@home (the FoldIt game is actually based on Rosetta) and produces models that have even been used by Folding@home. One of the nice things about Rosetta is that it runs on the BOINC platform, and has ARM compatibility, so you can run Rosetta on a spare Raspberry Pi or even your Android Smartphone where Folding@home focusses on desktop CPUs and GPUs. I have a few old phones running Rosetta along with a Pi 3 B+, and my desktop and an old surface running Folding@home
